The Silent Graveyard
 
 A Holocaust Poem:
 
 The bodies scattered
 Lying everywhere
 No one moves, nor makes a sound
 For the crack of the whip sounded
 
 Not much could be done
 The torturous place ended,
 The Fate already decided 
 For most; While some had time
 
 Then crying was heard
 As the children wailed
 Looking for parents or siblings
 Finding no one
 
 None were spared;
 Not even the youngest
 The old nor the lame
 All fell prey to hatred
 
 Not many survived
 Most were left for the dead
 They struck quickly
 Not being expected at all
 
 Some survived the last shots
 Stumbling along the bodies
 Reveling at those lost
 Trying to hold in weeps
 
 Everywhere sick
 Everyone dying
 Nearly forgetting those dead
 But not completely
 
 They returned like ghosts
 Rising from the dead
 Showing during the night
 Remembering those who left
 
 While they did nothing wrong
 And they were blamed for their race
 They never gave up
 Even as they dies one by one
 
 Nightmares of the pain
 Dreams of the long torture
 Days with long stares
 From people who never cared
 
 Coming back to nothing
 Everything being changed
 The women and men
 No longer separate; But one
 
 Trying to still breath 
 But in a place with no air
 Never being right again
 Never being able to close their eyes
 
 The pain they went through
 Unimaginable to most
 Seeing things by babies
 That even adults shouldn't see
 
 But their story is not lost
 Their struggling never to be left
 Remembered always;
 Forgotten not
 
 As we remember their stories
 And we try not to picture it
 We are forever reminded
 Of what we couldn't help
 
 Pictures of starvation
 Pictures of disease
 Things we could never fathom
 Done by an evil man
 
 It's hard to imagine
 How we escaped what they couldn't
 How we had gotten off easily;
 How we weren't touched
 
 As to why it all happened
 No one really knows
 But it can't ever be forgotten
 As we remember the Silent Graveyard 
 
 
 (C) Ashley Ward All Rights Reserved 2009
 
 Criticism would be nice!

 not worth stealing

not worth stealing

 
 Thanks?
 
 Because, you know, that's what every aspiring professional writer would like to hear!
 
 But thanks for your honesty.

I wasn't sarcastic.
 
 There is a lot of feeling in your words, but no poetry.
 
 You see, we all have feelings but, poetry requires more than telling others what we feel.
 
 The above is only my humble opinion, I am no expert on literary matters, so disregard it if you so wish.

LETTER TO TSVETAEVA
 
 
 Ah, now your time has come, Marina.
 You visit me at night while I sit alone.
 With a glass of wine in hand
 ¬—you who do not need a key—
 for you the most secret door of my room
 is always open:
 abandoned by our mothers,
 we both loved children and poetry,
 and hated Paris and poverty,
 wearing the one and only dirty dress,
 we kept clear of landlords and cops.
 
 We both had blue eyes, many lovers,
 and the incapacity to live with anyone.
 Ah, I almost forgot: our fathers, too,
 had similar jobs—they occupied themselves
 with museums and art …
 Still, I got angry yesterday
 When someone called me Marina …
 I’m neither important nor odd enough
 to send daily reports to Beria …
 How furious I was that you hanged yourself!
 What courage, what a double cross, what a lie,
 what a betrayal of poetry ..
 Marina, I’m a child as you can see,
 about you and life I really know nothing.
 
 —Nina Zivancevic
 
 (Translated from the Serbian by Charles Simic)
